description:
The Input Formatter plugin enables the formatting of input fields in your Bubble app to a specific structure such as credit cards, dates, and numbers (with thousands separators). It allows you to define custom formats and apply specific delimiters, prefixes, and letter case, giving you complete control over how user inputs are presented and stored.

[b]Usage Features:[/b] 

- Supports predefined formats such as credit card numbers, dates, and numeric formats with thousands separators, or you can define a custom format.
- You can set custom delimiters for separating values, such as hyphens for credit card numbers or slashes for dates.
- Allows adding prefixes or suffixes to inputs, which is useful for currencies or other domain-specific needs.
- Converts input text to uppercase or lowercase automatically, or restricts input to only letters.
- Flexibility to define date formats (e.g., m/d/Y) for various localization needs.

[size=5][b]FAQ[/b][/size]

- [b]What input formats are supported by this plugin?[/b]
You can format inputs for credit card numbers, dates, numeric values (e.g., with thousands separators), or define your own custom format.

- [b]Can I customize the delimiters in input formatting?[/b]
Yes, you can specify custom delimiters, such as hyphens, slashes, or any other characters to structure the input as needed.

- [b]How do I apply uppercase or lowercase formatting to the input?[/b]
The plugin has settings that allow you to automatically convert all input to either uppercase or lowercase text.

- [b]Can I format date inputs to match specific regional formats?[/b]
Yes, you can define the format for date inputs using placeholders such as m/d/Y, which gives you the flexibility to match regional date formatting preferences.

name: Input Formatter
plugin_instructions:
To use, you have to point the Input Formatter element to the ID of the Input element you want to format.
In your project settings, under General, make sure "Expose the option to add an ID attribute to HTML elements" is enabled. 
Now go to your Input's properties, at the bottom you will see "ID attribute". Add a name here, then in the Input Formatter properties, add it under Input ID.
